column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: We operate in 35 countries where our 57,000 employees are working to find better ways to provide the materials the world needs. Our portfolio includes iron ore, copper, aluminium and a range of other minerals and materials needed for people, communities and nations to grow and prosper and for the world to cut carbon emissions to zero. We continuously search for new projects that can support the energy transition, currently exploring eight commodities in 18 countries.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: We base our appointments to the Board on merit and objective selection criteria, aiming to bring a range of skills, knowledge and experience to Rio Tinto. It involves a formal and rigorous process to source strong candidates from diverse backgrounds and conduct appropriate background and reference checks on the shortlisted candidates. We aim to appoint people who will help us address the company's operational and strategic challenges and opportunities and ensure that our Board is diverse in experience, gender, nationality, social background and cognitive style.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: With the Board's full support, our executive team is driving this change, reinforcing the importance of mindsets and behaviours that ensure everyone in our operations feels safe, valued and empowered.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Sustainability Committee helps the Board oversee strategies to manage social and environmental risks, including management processes and standards, and comply with social and environmental responsibilities and commitments. The Committee reviews the effectiveness of management policies and procedures relating to safety, health, employment practices, relationships with neighbouring communities, environment, human rights, land access, political involvement and sustainable development.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Sustainability Committee oversees Rio Tinto's frameworks, management systems and processes for ensuring the health and safety of our employees and contractors; monitors our vital environmental risks such as water, tailings management and biodiversity; and supports the Group's contribution to the sustainable development of the communities in which we operate.

The Board is satisfied that all its Non-Executive Directors are independent in character and judgement and are accessible from any relationships (material or otherwise) or circumstances that could create a conflict of interest.
The Committee Chair reports to the Board after each meeting, and our minutes are tabled before the Board. All Directors have access to the Committee's papers.

We can raise concerns about any behaviours that do not align with our values or might break the law. These can cover violations of our standards, policies and procedures (including this Code), issues relating to harmful and disrespectful behaviours (including sexual harassment, racism, discrimination, bullying and harassment), human rights, safety, environment, financial reporting, fraud or business integrity issues in general.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: An effective Board combines a range of perspectives with strong oversight, combining the experience of Directors who have developed a deep understanding of our business over several years with the fresh insights of newer appointees. We aim for the Board's composition to reflect the global nature of our business - we currently have eight different nationalities (including dual nationalities) on a Board of 14.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: We undertake a formal annual evaluation of the effectiveness of the Board, and every third year, we engage a professional external adviser to carry out an independent review.

column13: Base salaries are set to reflect broad alignment with comparable roles in the global external market and the executive's qualifications, responsibilities and experience. Base salaries are reviewed annually by the Committee, and any increase is typically aligned with the broader workforce, with a maximum individual annual growth of 5% plus the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

Other strategic, environmental, social and governance (ESG) and individual business outcomes may be included.

Following decommissioning the EMIX Global Mining Index in 2023, our TSR will be measured against the S&P Global Mining Index and the MSCI World Index. Opportunity increased from 400% to 500% of base salary with the additional 100% of base salary linked to tangible decarbonisation targets.

Rio Tinto's strategic importance in helping societies resolve their most urgent challenges is evident. Rio Tinto can be fundamental to the energy transition. Our industry has been and will continue to be relied upon to provide the vast quantities of metals and minerals needed to build the infrastructure for generating, transmitting, and storing renewable power.

We are committed to deepening connections with our stakeholders to earn trust, resolve conflicts, and strengthen our social licence. It is a constant work in progress, but there were many bright spots in how our relationships with governments, communities and Indigenous Peoples evolved in 2023.

We approached the year with confidence in our strategy, a deep commitment to safety and financial discipline, and a continuous improvement mindset. By continuing to focus on our four objectives, we have put Rio Tinto in a stronger position to capture traditional and emerging opportunities. In 2023, we returned to investing in profitable growth with an eye to the future.

Innovation and technology drive our progress, helping us simplify and automate for safer and more efficient operations. Our project pipeline has real momentum, and our Chief Scientist's office is steering us towards more sustainable mining and processing breakthroughs, including BlueSmeltingTM, ELYSISTM and BioIronTM.

column13: Building everyday respect progressed in 2023, with the deployment of the Everyday Respect training program (Building Everyday Respect through care, courage and curiosity) across our organisation. The program's goal is to set the foundational elements of psychological safety at a Group level and to emphasise the role everyone plays in creating a psychologically safe, respectful, and inclusive work environment.
column20: Respect, Training Program, Code of Conduct

column13: In early 2023, we launched The Way We Work, our updated Code of Conduct, available at riotinto.com/ethics. It is designed to help all employees and contractors live our values of care, courage and curiosity and is a central tool in reshaping our culture.

Business integrity underpins everything we do. It requires that no matter where we are from or work, we demonstrate consistent ethical behaviours, put integrity at the centre of our decisions, and hold each other accountable for our choices.
